sen.j: 寺格（じかく）は、経済的もしくは身分的に区分された寺院の等級を設けて、格式を区別すること。
sen.e: Jikaku was a hierarchy of a Buddhist temple used to classify its status based on its economic and social standing.

sen.j: その寺院の創建などの由緒によって、封戸、出挙イネ、寺田、荘園所有等の権益、三綱（僧の官位）・別当あるいは住持職の任免、修法の方法、服装等の待遇などで区別を行う。
sen.e: Criteria used for the classification include history of the temple such as its foundation; interests such as fuko (residential units (ko) assigned as prebends (fu) to support top-ranking officials, temples, shrines, and royal households), rice used for suiko (government loans made to peasants), temple fields and ownership of shoen; and treatments such as appointment and dismissal of Sango (three monastic positions with management roles at a temple) (a rank of priesthood), betto or jujishoku (resident head of a temple), practice method and attire.

Temples are differentiated depending upon the temple's lineage and when it was founded etc: rights and interests of assets such as fuko (a vassal household allotted to a courtier), rice tributes, temple lands, manor property holdings; handling of appointment of Sango (three monastic positions with management roles at a temple), stewards or chief priest's role, prayer methods, dress etc.

sen.e: There were other criteria that were used to classify temples; jiryo (temple estate) was used to distinguish shuin dera (temples whose territories are authorized by the bakufu with shuinjo (red-sealed shogunate license)) from kokuin dera (temples whose territories are authorized by daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) with kokuinjo (black-sealed shogunate license)); color of monks' robes was used to distinguish shie dera (temples of priests who are allowed to wear shie (priest's purple garb)) from koe dera (temples of priests who are allowed to wear koe (priest's garb in light brown with a tinge of yellow); and ceremonial liturgy was used to designate dokureiji (temples allowed to see the Emeperor or shogun exclusively).
